segments.text: Okay, Ray.
Okay, this is Ron Shorn interviewing Ray Newbern at Jet Propulsion Laboratory at Pasadena, California on June 16, 1993.
Ray, for the record, what's your full name?
Ray Leon Newbern, Jr. And where and when were you born?
January 9, 1933, Rock Island, Illinois.
Okay.
How did you get interested in astronomy in the first place?

I read a Sunday supplement in a newspaper when I was in the fourth grade, probably at that time, in the old Herald Examiner, except I guess it was the Herald Express in those days, before they combined with the Examiner.
Got very excited about this article about the solar system.
Started asking my folks questions.
They didn't know the answers.
Said, you know what you're supposed to do when you...
want the answer to something, and we don't know the answer, go to the library.
So I started reading books on astronomy, and the next thing I knew, I was hooked.
Okay.
Did you keep that interest in astronomy through high school?
Yes, very much so.
Where did you go to high school, by the way?
Glendale High, Glendale, California.
So where did you go to undergraduate school?
Well, just tell me your schooling.
I went to Caltech in September of 1950.
Got my bachelor's degree there in 1954, a master's degree in 55.
I did the coursework for a doctorate.
And then in the summer of 56, I came to work at JPL rather than continuing as I had in a couple of previous summers at Mount Wilson Observatory because I was $3,500 in debt and needed the money.
JPL offered me twice as much money as Mount Wilson.
So I came to work at JPL, and it turns out I never went back to school then.
I stayed at JPL, been here just over 37 years now.
What did JPL hire you to do?
Well, the first job I did that I was really looking at seriously was the flame attenuation of electromagnetic radiation.
They were still doing radio guidance in those days, and they were concerned about the radio signals for guidance
being attenuated by the rocket plume.
And so it was a problem in pure physics.
There was no real astronomy here, and that's what I was doing that summer.
Was that Sergeant or Corporal?
Actually, in those days, it was, I think, a concern about both.
Both were certainly... Corporal was in the field, and Sergeant was still under development.
When did
When did JPL start getting interested in astronomy?

Well, the first action that I got involved in that was really astronomy occurred when Marsha Neugebauer and I wrote a series of articles, or articles, but just position papers on some of the things that we might do in space in early 1958.
This was in response to Explorer 1 having gone up and people starting to think ahead as to what it might be possible to do with these newfangled rockets and space probes.
And the result of that position paper, which was strictly an on-lab thing, was that I was made part of a Tiger team set up by Al Hibbs in the fall of 1958.
to formally look into these problems of what should we do in our studies of the solar system.
And this all finally resulted in Marsha and I writing the report 30-1, which was the formal report of Al Hibbs' Tiger Team, and we did the science section.
Okay, did that report have any, did anything come out of that?
Yeah, I mean, it was accepted by NASA, and I think it was widely used initially as a sort of an outline of the things we ought to be attempting to do in space.
And it was very widely used and quoted for a few years until we began to try to do some of these things.
Found some of them were a little harder than we thought.
But actually, I think virtually everything in that report we finally did.
Maybe not quite on the time scale we expected.
Took a little longer, but we finally did it all.
When did you get to be able to start to do some astronomy at JPL?
Well, we created an astronomy group here in, I believe, 1961.
People were convinced that we needed some astronomers around doing astronomy to maintain, I think,
recognition in the field and to give proper advice and mostly we were concerned about the fact that there was almost no planetary astronomy going on in the United States in those days.
We knew that we were going to need ground-based support of the space program.
No one else seemed willing to do it so we got the idea well let's see what we can do in a small way ourselves and when a small 16-inch
The telescope came on the market for, I believe, $8,000.
It was for sale by a private party here in the basin.
I talked the boss into buying it and housing it.
In those days, it was Al Hibbs was the division manager.
Fred Eimer was his deputy.
And, gosh, who was the section manager?
Shortly after that, Luke Kaplan came on board as the section manager.
I think at the time this actually happened, it was probably either Herb Trostle or John Porter.
Alright, so you got this 16-inch, and where'd you put it?
We looked at several possibilities.
I talked to Ira Bowen, and he had agreed that we could use a site just north of the 100-inch dome on Mount Wilson.

But, of course, we would have been distinctly visitors, and he said that their facilities were sufficiently loaded and water was short, and we'd have to bring in everything that we wanted to use and stay in the old Mount Wilson Hotel and what have you.
We looked at Chileo, but we looked longest and hardest and finally went in to Table Mountain because the Smithsonian was just moving out.
They had done solar constant work there for some...

25 or 30 years I guess there were primitive facilities there already and the Forest Service was happy to have someone take over the site so we and of course we had seeing studies as well for the site since it had been one of the areas where Caltech had looked as a possible site for the 200 inch reflector and they found that it was as good as Palomar from the point of view of astronomical seeing
And at that time, from the point of view of city lights, but it was very close to the San Andreas Fault.
So they went to Palomar instead of to Table Mountain.
But we had all those seeing studies, and we knew it was a good site.
So we grabbed it.
Who were the early people that were hired on?
I guess Highspinrad was one of the earliest to come in after you formed your astronomical section.
Highspinrad, Bob Youngkin.
Yourself, Ron Shorn, were the first people that were involved.
We hired a man by the name of Charles Cape, and he went by the name Chick, who would actually act as the on-site manager, supervisor, holder of hands, repairer of problems, and so on at the mountain.
I know where High and I came from.
Do you remember where Bob Youngkin came from?
He was actually working on his doctorate at UCLA at the time.
And he was married, family, and needed to work.
And so he was just working on his doctorate in his spare time.
And he did finally finish it years later.
I guess you got interested in planetary astronomy right from the start, right?
From the Sunday supplement?
That's true.
Although when I was a student at Caltech, my work and my interests lay mostly in galactic structure and cosmology.
And my published work there, a major paper that I did, was on the RR Lyrae variables in NGC 4147, published in the AJ the year I came to work at the lab.
But

here of course the interest was in planetary and i loved astronomy generally so i at that time it was easily possible for a person to know everything there was to know about the field of solar system astronomy quite unlike today and so i just sort of made myself a universalist on the solar system uh back say in 1958 or 1960 uh your opinion
Did real, quote unquote, astronomers look down on planetary types?
Very much so.
Did you feel inferior?
Not really, no.
Because you were working on planets.
I didn't think so.
I thought that most of the attitude that astronomers had was because of a few unfortunate articles of people who tended to follow Percival Lowell's school of study of Mars and that
The Sunday supplements, in fact, even though one is what attracted me to the field, had given the people who were interested in the solar system a bad name.
But if one looked, one found people like G.P.
Kuiper, who was doing good, reputable work.
Of course, the people at Mount Wilson, like Dunham and Adams and Nicholson and Pettit, had done good work, solid physical, astrophysical work on the planets throughout the 30s.
And Kuiper picked it up in the 40s.
And it was a perfectly good, honest field.

It's just that it had gotten a little bit of a bad rep that people who didn't know too much about it tended to look at the infamous Lowellian school of the solar system instead of the solid physical work.
Do you think planetary astronomy and planetary astronomers are considered respectable today by the other astronomers?
I think very much so.
I do not feel today that they draw any distinction as to the quality of a person because he works in the field of solar system research rather than in stellar or galactic research.
I think that

most modern astronomers probably feel that this study may not be quite as fundamental shall we say as studying the big bang or trying to solve some of the what they consider basic problems of the first few seconds of the universe or the missing mass or or the great attractor or the great celestial voids or what have you but i don't think they
They probably look at it as sort of a different field, almost like biology and chemistry are a different field, not necessarily inferior, but just different and not as interesting to them.
Again, back when you got started doing this, say around 1960, what was planetary astronomy like in the U.S.?
It was almost non-existent.
Really, G.P.
Kuiper...
was the only one who was doing modern physical observing of the planets at that particular time that I can think of off the top of my head.
We had a very few people in celestial mechanics, about six of them, I think.
We had Clements and Brower and Hergott and Herbig, not Herbig, Robbie, Herrick, the other one I was trying to think of.
That was just about it.
Brown of the lunar theory was dead by then.

And in fact, there were so few people even who knew celestial mechanics that when the space program hit, the lab started shipping people en masse back to a special summer school that Dirk Brouwer held at Yale to teach people what celestial mechanics was all about.
The subject wasn't even taught at Caltech, for example.
Where do you think planetary astronomy would be now if it wasn't for the money NASA has spent in the last 30 years?
Obviously it would be a very, very different field.
I don't think
If we didn't have the space program, I think there would still be a few isolated individuals who would study the planets from time to time.
Any time you get new techniques, new instruments, new equipment, somebody's going to apply them to the obvious objects that are near at hand, like the planets.
But I don't think it would have, well, much of our knowledge has clearly been found by the space probes, possibly
I don't know, maybe a quarter as much of it has been found from the ground.
And I don't think there would have been but a fraction of that if it hadn't been for NASA and the space program.
I think the interest would not have been there.
The people wouldn't have been attracted to the field.
The telescopes wouldn't have been available for this less interesting work, less fundamental work, as it were.
I think it's no question that NASA and the coming space program changed the whole field.
Do you think that planetary astronomy is a part of astronomy?
Yes, I do.
I think that there are many people in the field whose background is more

geology or meteorology than it is astronomy, but I think astronomers play a particular role, especially in the study of objects like comets and asteroids, the small bodies of the solar system, where they're still basically not looking at geological or meteorological processes.
And similarly, with many of the satellites in the solar system, I think we all have something
to contribute.
And one of the interesting things about modern solar system astronomy is that it isn't just astronomy, but it's also geology and meteorology.
And I think everybody works together very well.
Back when this stuff started in the early 60s,
You were in a special situation because JPL is actually a contractor to NASA through Caltech.
And how was astronomy funded at JPL in those days?
Did headquarters give a block grant to Caltech to be given to JPL to be used as JPL saw fit?
Or did they say exactly what they wanted?
This is in the early 60s when this stuff began.
I was, of course, a very junior person at JPL in those days.
I do not know for sure exactly how it was funded.
I know that initially I simply got my money from my superiors, and if they thought what I wanted to do was right, then they found me the money to do it.
So my guess is it was probably a block grant.
I know that when I began building the Table Mountain Observatory and that I had a...
brand, if you will, although it was not the result of a proposal.
I simply sent a proposal to NASA, as it were.
It wasn't reviewed as they are today, and they decided if what I proposed to do was reasonable, and they sent me the money to run the
ground-based astronomy program at Table Mountain, for example, and to fund a number of people to work on it and work there.
So in that sense, it was a block grant, not to JPL.
It came in that case to me, and I was responsible for it.
But earlier, it had come to my bosses,
So I suppose you would call that a block grant.
It certainly was not money to an individual to do a specific kind of work.
And how's it done today?
Today, of course, it is very much the individual who is funded.
If the individual leaves, the money goes with him or her.
And that money is on the basis of competitive proposals to do specific things.
And it is...
much today as if you were working in a university going to NASA or to the NSF for funds.
It's a totally different approach to doing the research.
It in some ways is not as pleasant of course.
It was much easier when if you saw something new and exciting and interesting you could jump into it without having to worry about whether this was covered in your
proposal and exactly what you would plan to do, but I suppose it also left possibilities for people to not do exactly what was right.
As I recall, back in the early 60s, those of us that were observing kind of did what we could.
There was so much to do.
How is it done today?

I mean, does the section chief or division chief say, we shall study Pluto this year, and everybody follows, or since now everybody has to get grants on their own, do they propose what they want to do?
Individuals propose what they want to do today.
I think any section manager in the science division at JPL who tried to tell an individual what he had to work on would sort of be laughed out of town.
Unless, of course, he had money and the individual wanted the money, then that's something else again.
But in general,
left up to the individual today.
This is true to a large extent.
However, in times when billets become tight, then it may be that the lab or the division or the section may decide that, hey, we've got to cut back a little bit.
And so they may look at those activities which seem less related to the flight programs of NASA and of the laboratory and decide that,

let's not say decide, let's sort of suggest to the person that if he or she wants to continue in employment at the lab, it might be better to look for a new field that is more akin to the needs of the laboratory.
However, that person, of course, if he or she has money, can take that money and go elsewhere and do it.
JPL never did get a big telescope on Table Mountain.
Not really, no.
We tried, of course, and that's a big story in and of itself.

However, in recent years, we did get from the Air Force the old 48-inch ALT-ALT-AS telescope that was at Cloudcroft, and this now has been erected on Table Mountain and, in fact, is going into regular scheduled observation in about two weeks.
There is also a 40-inch reflector on Table Mountain that is owned by Pomona College
And the time on that telescope is available, half of the time is available to people at JPL.
What instrumentation, and also you have a 24-inch, is that still in operation?
24-inch is very much in operation.
It's been the one instrument that has produced pretty good science throughout all of the years that Table Mountain has existed, which number roughly 30 now.

uh well of course the 24 inch wasn't there initially it came in a few years later but let's say 25 years yeah it's uh it's has a large good a spectrograph on it which was heavily used at first has been more lightly used in recent years but i guess there are people planning to to bring it back into full use again there's been a great deal of photoelectric photometry and uh
imaging with CCDs and prior to that Vidicon type detectors on the 24 inch.
What kind of foci do the 40 inch and 48 inch have that are available?
I've never seen the 40 inch.
I have no idea what is available there.
In the case of the 48 inch, again, I haven't been on the mountain now in more than 10 years.
I have information here that I can give you that shows the exact instrumentation and foci and so on on the 48-inch, but I shouldn't really say off the top of my head.
We'll get to that later.
You mentioned that JPL's attempt to get a decent-sized, a big telescope of a 100-inch class is a long story.
Let's talk about some of that story.
How did the idea start?
Or was it obvious to everyone that you needed a dedicated planetary telescope?
Well, I think with all of us here, it was obvious to us when we went out and tried to get time on existing large telescopes that that time simply was not available for planetary work.
All of the telescopes were very busy.
And even in those days, there were more astronomers wanting time than there was time available.
And when good young people could not
get time at the major instruments, it was pretty obvious that we needed a major instrument of our own.
And I couldn't say that any one person was responsible for that idea.
It was a very obvious one.
If you can't get the time you need, you better build your own.
And that, in fact, was what was suggested by people like Ira Bowen, who was then the director at Mount Wilson.
And he, in fact, helped a great deal in pushing NASA into the idea that they needed to build their own telescope for planetary astronomy.
He certainly agreed that there was still a great deal of good, solid astrophysical work on the planet that could be done with modern equipment.
He was, I think, a very honest, straightforward, actually rather far-thinking individual who
recognized the fact that there was a great deal left to be done from the ground.
And he gave a lot of good advice to NASA, suggesting that they should go ahead and build their own telescope.
I got Homer Newell to sign two things.
And one was for a telescope at McDonald Observatory at the University of Texas.
And one was for what I thought was going to be a telescope on Table Mountain.
Whatever happened about that time I left headquarters?
Caltech, unfortunately, is what happened.
The feeling was that since we were young and not well known, and there were a lot of famous astronomers at Caltech, that this ought to be some kind of a joint effort between Caltech and JPL.
Unfortunately, what JPL wanted was a good telescope in a good site that could get to work in a hurry, doing...
astronomical research.
What Caltech wanted was a really new, modern, earth-shaking telescope in the world's very best possible site.
And their idea was to perhaps do a five-year seeing survey, and some work was actually done on that.
Telescopes were mounted at White Mountain, for example, for a time, and
We got information from Berkeley, who had also mounted a seeing study up there.
But they really began looking for the world's greatest site for a planetary telescope, thinking that seeing was all important in planetary detail work.
And they had a very long range plan.
I think that what it finally came down to was that their idea of what needed to be done and ours were so different, and I think both
Well, NASA also wanted to get on the air, so to speak.

So we could never reach an agreement with Caltech that we both felt comfortable with and finally wound up, as I understood it, with the money going to Hawaii, which of course was a very superior site, as it turned out.
Right, but which had no astronomers whatsoever except a few solar types.
That's right.
Then there was another project that I guess finally became the infrared telescope facility in Lunakea, the light bucket.
Do you remember the light?
JPL was going to build a light bucket.
How did that get started?
Was Frank Gray involved in that or something like that?
I never knew the details on that one, Ron.
I wish I had.
Frank Gray was the assistant section manager in those days, and he could very well have been heavily involved in it.
But by that time, I was not heavily involved any longer in the field.
I had pushed hard to build a...
I had even the blueprints in my office for the 84-inch Kitt Peak, which we were proposing to duplicate to save time.
Again, here was an existing working telescope, and we had a complete set of blueprints for it, and it would have been easy and cheap to simply duplicate everything at Table Mountain.
When that money didn't come, we had preliminary designs for a 48-inch, preliminary designs for a 60-inch.
We got none of those.
And when it became obvious the telescope was going elsewhere, in fact, I got heavily involved in other areas, in particular in work on comets and advanced comet missions.
And part of the problem was that I didn't have my Ph.D.,
And at that time, I had a division manager who didn't go by what you did, but by what your credentials were.
Who was?
Robert Magreblian.
And he moved me out of the slot as head of the astronomy group and put me in charge of a group which was doing models of the planets for the projects.
And I did that and various advanced studies.

And then from there, I started studying comet missions, got extremely interested in comets, and began my own research program in cometary astrophysics, and started going to other observatories and working with other people, and sort of divorced myself from the astronomy program at JPL.
I tried to do some work at Table Mountain, but it was so ill-funded by the mid-'70s that we didn't have the manpower to even keep the auxiliary instrumentation running properly.
And so from the mid-'70s on, I worked on advanced studies at JPL of comet missions and then did my own research at other places like Mauna Kea and later at Lick Observatory.
That brings up an interesting question.
Through the 20s and 30s and 40s,
when solar system studies in general have a bad odor about them.
It was always legitimate to study comets.
Why?
Well, comets, I guess, didn't have any thoughts on anybody's part about life and the solar system and a little green man.
comets were simply a phenomenon that had fascinated mankind throughout history.
They were an interesting astrophysical problem, both as to their origin and to the way they work.
What in the heck are they?
What are they made of?
And why do they behave the way they do?
And their problems were sufficiently enigmatic that they had always fascinated even the classical stellar astronomer.
And indeed, they remained a subject that was always considered quite a legitimate one for study.
And it's sort of ironic that the very objects which did remain of interest to the classic stellar and galactic astronomer are the single object to which NASA has never mounted a mission.
What do you think killed planetary astronomy in the early part of this century, effectively killed it?
I know some was being done, but if you look at the journals in 1900 and then you look at 1930, wow, is there a difference.
What's the reason, or reasons?
Well, I think there are, to my way of thinking, off the top of my head, a couple of things can be said about it.
For one thing, large telescopes became available

which gathered a great deal of light and allowed people to do high-resolution spectroscopy, to go deep into the universe studying the extragalactic nebulae, the galaxies, the expansion of the universe.
These problems were totally fascinating.

But if you wanted to study the planets with a large telescope, obviously you didn't get any better resolution with the large telescopes than you did with much smaller ones simply because you were atmospheric seeing limited.

People in those days didn't know how much of that seeing was created locally by uncontrolled thermal problems, but in any case, a big telescope wasn't that much better than a little one for studying the kind of planetary work that people had traditionally done, which is to say planetary detail, the kind of thing that Percival Lowell had done.
So they sort of went off and developed new instrumentation and went off into the universe.
There were always a few people who remained in the field, including some with the biggest telescope in the world, 100 inch at that time.

But I think it was the fascination with the deep space problems and the fact that the big telescopes couldn't do that much more than the little ones could in those times on the planets that allowed the planetary field to simply die.
Do you think NSA headquarters tries to micromanage scientific projects too much?
Well, not in the individual research particularly.
I mean, they manage it in the sense that they decide how much money is available for stellar astronomy versus planetary astronomy versus Earth.
And really, if you look at it, the only reason they support this research at all is because of the very complementary way that it blends in with their spaceflight missions.
But their real interest is in the missions, and they're simply supporting them with this ground-based research.
I think they don't try to tell an individual what he has to do.

On the other hand, the amount of money that's available in a given field is certainly a function of their interest in it and, well, the universe we live in, why the guy who has the bucks calls the shots.
Do you think over the years the people at headquarters really knew what was going on in planetary astronomy or were they playing catch-up?
Well, let's face it, most of them were not planetary astronomers themselves.
There have been obvious exceptions to that, yourself among them.
But no person sitting in Washington can really retain a feel for the work in the field.
It's virtually impossible, to my way of thinking, for a person with a job in Washington
retain a research program of his own or her own.
The exceptions are very forced.
I think if the people running the programs at headquarters were handled perhaps the way section managers are in the science sections at JPL, that is on an alternating, rotating two-year basis,
where they remained scientists a good part of the time, but then filled in and devoted a couple of years to seeing after NASA's interest, maybe that would be a solution.
But it has been my experience that generally when people go to Washington,

The very, very fine people that often go there simply after a time become so involved in their own worries about their programs that they lose any feel for or sight of the real research and the real interests of the people in the field actually doing the work.
What do you think the public thinks of planetary astronomy and astronomy in general?
I think they're fascinated by it, probably for a lot of wrong reasons.

I'm sure that when they think of the solar system, they're thinking, again, even in the classic Lowellian sense of little green men, and there's certainly a lot of fanatics out there in the UFO field and what have you that have a lot of interest in this sort of thing, but it's all misplaced.
On the other hand, I think the young people find...
real modern astronomy fascinating.

Obviously, again, they're somewhat steered in that direction by the Star Wars and Star Trek kind of phenomenon, but I think it gives them a healthy interest in science, and I think they're genuinely interested.
I'm not sure that it's always brought to them in the proper way.
I'm sure that many adults
don't understand it at all, and perhaps poo-poo it, but I think the younger generation has a genuine interest in astronomy, both solar system and deep space astronomy.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done as good a job as they could of putting your case across to the public and to Congress?
Probably not.
Let's face it, scientists in general are not necessarily salespeople.
There have been a few obviously very good salespeople for planetary astronomy, like Carl Sagan.
And Carl, I think, usually has done a good job of selling it, although there

Maybe some things that he's done that weren't in our best interest, but I think he's a straightforward and honest and well-meaning guy who's done an awful lot to help sell the space program to Congress and to the world.
I think we could use a few more, a little different maybe, but a few more similar people.
But I'm sure that the likes of you and I have not
perhaps done our part and perhaps are not capable of doing the sales job that needs to be done.
Thirty years ago, there was just an American Astronomical Society.
Now there's a lot of sub-societies, particularly there's the Division for Planetary Astronomy, which even has its own official journal, Icarus.
What are these developments?
Do you think on the whole that they've been good, bad, or just inevitable?
I think they've been good in the sense that it would have been very difficult for planetary astronomy to grow if it had remained totally under the thumb of the parent society.
By having its own organization and its own journal and its own prizes, why, it could develop as an entity and a very strong one in its own right.
And I think it would have been almost impossible for this to happen under the thumb of the parent society.
These days do you think that real quote-unquote astronomers and planetary astronomers talk to each other very much?

I think they do, maybe not as much as they should, but there is a very definite attempt to occasionally hold meetings of the parent society and the divisions jointly, and to have prize winners and so on from the divisions deliver prize lectures at the parent society.
I think there's much more appreciation for each other today, certainly, than there was 30 years ago.
The feelings are improving, which isn't to say that the stellar and galactic astronomers still don't feel that their field is the real astronomy and more important than solar system work.
And probably a lot of them tend to lump solar system astronomers into the class along with geologists and meteorologists as opposed to being real astronomers.
But I think they respect one another and are interested in each other's work to an extent.
Okay, for 35 years now, we've been going to planets and observing them from the ground and spacecraft and directly.
Not a trace of, not a trace of more fossil of any life anywhere in the solar system except Earth.
In particular, no trace of life so far on Mars.
Do you think that's had a big effect on the public and on funding?
Big negative effect or not?
Oh, boy, that's hard to say.
I think that astronomers never really expected to find any significant form of life anywhere in our solar system.
I think many, perhaps most of them, feel that there may be some form of life elsewhere in the galaxy and certainly in the universe.
It's an awfully big universe for this to only have happened once.
And whether you think about this from a purely scientific point of view or even from a religious point of view...
Why should God create such an enormous universe and only inhabit one teeny tiny mote of it?
And if you look at it from a purely biological evolutionary point of view, if it happened here, why can't it have happened somewhere else?
So I think most scientists probably feel somewhere in the universe there's life, other than here and here on Earth.
But none of us really expected to find it in the solar system.
The public in general probably did.
And some of them may be disappointed by it.

And I think that some of them are put off now, perhaps, by people trying to oversell programs on the basis of looking for life, even though it is still a legitimate thing to do to see if there's any evidence, let's say, on Mars of...
or of any form of life ever having existed.
This is a legitimate scientific study like any other, but it's not the kind of thing that's going to enchant the general public.
They want to see some walking and talking, or at least growling.
A lot of people lately have been getting a lot of publicity and some money for studying things like the possibility of planets around other stars.
Killer asteroids, ozone hole, ozone layer hole, and the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
Do you think those people are overdoing it a bit or not?
I think they're all legitimate fields of study.
I think that as virtually every program, they are oversold in the sense that they are giving love and motherhood statements, which are their ultimate goal.
The implication is that these programs are going to be solved with a few bucks in a short period of time when, in fact, they may not really say that, but the implication is there.
Whereas, in fact, most of these are very long-range programs.
and are going to have to be followed for many decades to have any real hope of success.
So I think there is a big tendency on everyone's part to try to oversell, because with the shortage of funds, everybody feels they've got almost half to oversell in order to get funded.
And that's unfortunate.
I mean, every one of those programs is a legitimate program, and it's a legitimate scientific study.
But I think they probably are oversold in that people tend to think that they're going to get results cheaper and sooner than they really are.
What's, in your opinion, what's the state of planetary astronomy today in this country?
Plus, minus, zero?
Well, I'm not sure what you mean by state.
Expanding, idling, sinking.

it's sinking i think i don't think there's any question of that the funding for planetary astronomy has not increased for a decade and there's been no real allowance made for inflation i think there's enormous pressure from the fact that any university professor is judged in part by the number of graduates that he has and the number of phds that he produces and you've got to figure if every

individual planetary astronomer out there in a university produces even five or six students, and most of them, it's probably more like 10 PhDs in the field during their working lifetime, you can see how rapidly the number of people in the field is going to grow, and each of them in turn then is going to have the same problem of getting funding and have their own students.
And so you tend to get an exponential growth.
And clearly no field can sustain an exponential growth for a long period of time.
Planetary astronomy has done it, did it for a couple of decades.
And clearly that has to stop.
So there's tremendous pressure just from there being too many people today for the funds that are available.
And you might argue that that's good for the field in that you can claim that the very best will rise to the top and be funded.
But I think it's not doing any young person a favor to take them into planetary astronomy today.
At least you have to be honest and explain the facts of life to them that they're going to have to be awfully good and work awfully hard if they're to have any real hope of succeeding in the field.
Over the years, what's JPL's attitude been?
Looking at it from the bottom, looking up, what do you think the people...
Well, what's the impression you got of what's JPL's quote-unquote attitude towards planetary astronomy?
Necessary evil, an ornament, or what?
I think the attitude at the lab has always been fairly good.
I think they found astronomers to be useful, well, all planetary scientists, not just astronomers, but all of the people in the field to be useful.
a useful adjunct in that they were around to help when questions came up on the flight projects.
And I think the feeling has been that the science produced here has been of sufficient quality for JPL to be quite proud of it.
And I think the attitude of senior management at the lab towards science has always been good.
It's never been, of course, their fundamental goal.
Their fundamental goal has always been and remains to sell
new projects.

So while I think the scientists are respected and have a place, everybody feels they have a place here, that place is not going to be allowed to interfere in any way with the lab's chief goals, which are to fly missions.
Do you think there's enough support for ground-based work as opposed to the money spent on probes by NASA?

I have to say no, in a way, in the sense that if you actually look at the dollars spent on probes through the last couple of decades and the dollars spent supporting ground-based work, the amount of knowledge that we've gained from the ground-based work is far larger proportionally than the money spent on it.
And as long as that continues to happen, then one has to argue that
perhaps there should be more funding for the ground-based work.
You're getting more bang for buck out of the ground-based stuff.
Now clearly there are many things that you cannot do from the ground.
You could never have done without the probes.
And so I'm not arguing to dismantle one in favor of the other.
I'm simply saying that I think perhaps their balance has always been a little bit off.
They get a lot of good data.
And then they have a brief research and analysis program on that data.
And before the treasure trove that they've gained with a probe is really worked out, the research program is cut off, and they go on to something else.
And I think that's short-sighted.
And I think, similarly, the actual support of ground-based observations has been a little lacking in, well, I think the balance is a little off.
Let me put it that way.
